name: a(n) = (6*n + 1)*(12*n + 1)*(18*n + 1).
comment: a(n) is a Carmichael number if all the three factors (6*n + 1), (12*n + 1), and (18*n + 1) are prime (see Chernick and Ribenboim).
reference: Paulo Ribenboim, The Little Book of Bigger Primes, Springer-Verlag NY 2004. See p. 101.
link: Jack Chernick, On Fermat's simple theorem, Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society, Vol. 45, No. 4 (1939), pp. 269-274.
Index entries for linear recurrences with constant coefficients, signature (4,-6,4,-1).
author: _Stefano Spezia_, Apr 05 2025

name: Numbers k such that 6*k+1, 12*k+1 and 18*k+1 are all primes.
comment: Main entry for this sequence is A033502.
k is a Carmichael number generator giving C(k) = (6*k+1)*(12*k+1)*(18*k+1) = A382809(k).
reference: R. K. Guy, Unsolved Problems in Number Theory, A13.
Ivan Niven, Herbert S. Zuckerman, and Hugh L. Montgomery, An Introduction to the Theory Of Numbers, Fifth Edition, Wiley NY 1991, page 83, problem #20.
Paulo Ribenboim, The Little Book of Bigger Primes, Springer-Verlag NY 2004. See p. 101.
link: Donovan Johnson, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Carmichael Number.
Index entries for sequences related to Carmichael numbers.
program: (PARI) is(n)=isprime(6*n+1) && isprime(12*n+1) && isprime(18*n+1) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jan 04 2022
author: _Eric W. Weisstein_
ext: Better description from _Robert G. Wilson v_, Sep 27 2000

name: Array read by ascending antidiagonals: A(n,k) = (6*n + 1)*(12*n + 1)*Product_{i=0..k-2} (9*2^i*n + 1) with k >= 2.
comment: A(n,k) is a Carmichael number with k prime factors if n is such all k factors are prime numbers and 2*k-4 divides n (see Ribenboim).
reference: Paulo Ribenboim, The Little Book of Bigger Primes, Springer-Verlag NY 2004. See p. 101.
author: _Stefano Spezia_, Apr 06 2025
